scene.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: part of a play during which there is no change in time or place
scene.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a single piece of action that happens in one place in a film, book etc
scene.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The film contains some violent scenes.
colourful pictures depicting scenes from the Bible
scene.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a particular set of activities and the people who are involved in them
scene.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I’m not into the club scene (=going to night clubs).
a newcomer to the political scene
scene.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: the place where an accident, crime etc happened
scene.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The police soon arrived at the scene of the crime.
Investigators are now at the scene, searching for clues.
Journalists were on the scene within minutes.
scene.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a view of a place as you see it, or as it appears in a picture
scene.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: He photographed a wide range of street scenes.
She returned home to find a scene of devastation.
scene.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: what is happening in a place, or what can be seen happening
scene.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: ‘It’s a bad scene here, ’ she said. ‘Jamie is very sick.’
There were scenes of rejoicing after the election.
scene.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: a loud angry argument, especially in a public place
scene.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: There were angry scenes in parliament today.
I was mad, but I didn’t want to make a scene.
